metadata.title: Modified Iron oxide nanomaterials: Functionalization and Application

sections.text:
Iron oxide magnetic nanoparticles have aroused the interest of researchers of materials’ chemistry due to its exceptional properties such as decent magnetic, electric, catalytic, biocompatibility, and low toxicity. However, these magnetic nanoparticles are predisposed towards aggregation and forming larger particles, due to its strong anisotropic dipolar interactions, particularly in the aqueous phase, consequently depriving them of dispersibility and particular properties, ultimately degrading their performance. Hence, this review focuses on modified magnetic nanoparticles that are stable, easily synthesized, possess a high surface area and could be facile-separated via magnetic forces, and are of low toxicity and costs for applications such as catalyst/catalyst support, food security, biomedical, and pollutant remediation.
Keywords: Magnetite; Nanoparticles; Functionalization; Magnetic properties
1.0 Introduction: Magnetic properties of Fe3O4 nanoparticles
Magnetic nanoparticles (MN) is regarded as an engineered particulate material that measures less than 100 nm with an external magnetic field. It also exhibits a phenomenon called superparamagnetism, where it does not magnetize under the influence of magnetic field, which eliminates the risk of particle aggregation [1-3]. MN have been widely utilized in various applications, such as magnetic resonance imaging, protein immobilization, biotechnology, catalysis, microwave absorber, and cancer therapy [Figure 1] [2-3]. The different synthesis process produces iron oxide with different external magnetic properties (Table 1).

Magnetite crystallizes in the inverse spinel structure (Fe 3+ ) (Fe 2+ , Fe 3+ ) to an FCC-close packed lattice of O2, where ½ of the octahedral sites are occupied by equal amounts of randomly distributed Fe 2+ and Fe 3+ , while 1/8 of the tetrahedral sites are occupied by the remaining Fe 3+
. Fe3O4 is thermodynamically stable under common ambient laboratory
environments, forming readily under most solvent-based nanoparticles synthesis conditions [1;4]. The bulk material is redox active, while the surface composition is easily varied by slight changes to O2 partial pressure and substrate temperatures. Upon exposure to the ambient atmosphere, the surface of macro-scaled Fe3O4 crystallites are often covered with multilayer of α-Fe2O3, and as is true with most oxides, with monolayer amounts of surface hydroxyl and physisorbed H2O [5-10].
Figure 1: Schematic representation of the magnetic relaxation mechanisms and the basic components of magnetic imaging system [3]
2.0 Modification of MN
There is substantial attention to the progress of stable, well dispersed, reusable, and
highly active MN [9;11-16]. There is mounting interest towards the modification of MN, where the nanoscale architecture of active centers influences the efficiency and selectivity.
2.1 Chemical functionalization of MN
2.1.1 Organic compound functionalized MN
With the aid of an external magnet, chemically-functionalized MN could be separated recycled and purified from the products with minimum operational costs. Novel properties such as biocompatibility, water-dispersible, biodegradability, and fundamental magnetic properties could be meant for functional organic materials attached to MN.
2.1.1.1 Acid-MN
In most cases, acid functionalized MN are investigated due to their easy separation from the reaction mixture via an external magnet. A promising acid compounds in this case is sulfuric acid (H2SO4) [17]. The H2SO4 functionalized silica-coated MN is recyclable, non toxic, capable, mild, and harmless to the environment. The solid acid catalyst creates new opportunities to create a remarkable and effective system that assists catalyst recovery in various organic reactions [17-18].
Recently, sulfamic acid (H3NSO3) which is a dry non-hygroscopic, nonvolatile, and order less solid has been used as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst alternative for conventional acidic catalyst [19-20]. The combination of H3NSO3 on the surface of MN is used as a catalyst for several one pot synthesis with a water medium at room temperature of acetalization, esterification, nitrile formation, tetrahydropyrnylation of alcohols, michael addition, and transesterification of β-ketoesters (Figure 2) [21-22]. For example, for the past few years, chlorosulfuric acid has been used to produce N-propylsulfamic acidfunctionalized magnetite Fe3O4 nanoparticles. It is a dry non-volatile and odourless solid, and has been demonstrated as a competent heterogeneous catalyst [22-23]. Furthermore, certain studies have focused on a combination of H3NSO3 and MN as catalysts for the synthesis of quinolone derivative treatment of 2-amino bensophenone with various carbonyl compounds, reporting a high yield (72 to 98 %) under solvent-free conditions [24].
dispersing MN in aqueous solution of sodium dodecylbenzene sulfonate, poly(oxyethylene)nonylphenyl ether, or di(2-ethyhexy) adipate [25-26]. The second surfactant could coat the primary surfactant to form a structured surfactant bilayers. Several studies have prepared a bilayer surfactant-stabilized magnetic fluid with the initial fatty acid layer and a secondary layer of other surfactants [27]. MN synthesis has been also performed in aqueous solution coated with bilayer C18H34O2. Moreover, the synthesis of bilayer C18H34O2 stabilized MN was accomplished using C18H34O2 as the primary and secondary layer surfactant [25]. The procedure reliably generates colloidal systems that are stable for more than 3 months, which is verified when no precipitate was formed after that time [28-29].
For extensive biological application, the amount of unbound or free C18H34O2 needs to be decreased for further reduction in the cytotoxicity of the formulation. For biomedical application, the ratio of the bound-to-free C18H34O2 can have significant impacts on the interaction of MN with oleic acid with regards to the mode of internalization and toxicity [27-29].
2.1.1.2 Silane-MN
The silane (SiH4) agents, including mercaptopropyltriethoxysilane, 3- aminopropyltriethyloxysilane, and p-aminophenyl trimethoxysilane are frequently deliberated as prospective candidates in order to manipulate the surface of MN [30-32]. This surface manipulation improves the biocompatibility, highly stable under fluorescent, and arrange for moderately high density surface functional end groups, which helps connect it to other metals, polymers, and biomolecules. After salinization, the core shell MN was treated with ammonia to create a bond with active COOH. The presence of many OH groups on the MN surface leads to reactions with alkoxysilane reagents, brought about by the construction of Si-O bonds, which supports the terminal functional groups available for immobilization of other substances [30;32].
Some studies have employed magnetic support to increase the affinity of MN towards SiH4 derivatives [33-34]. For example, tetraethyl orthosilate has been employed to present a highly reactive silanols (Si-OH) on the surface of MN to develop its interactions with γ-aminopropyltriethoxysilane an organosilane, which is a bifunctional molecule having a trialkoxy group (which can bind covalently to the free OH groups on the surface of particles) and an organic head group functionality that defines the final chemical character of the modified surface [35-36].
2.1.1.3 Amino-MN
Amino (C2NH4O2R) functionalized magnetic nanopartciles are universally employed for conjugation with biomolecules and drugs [37]. As conductive molecules, C2NH4O2R has been extensively incorporated with MN for enzyme immobilization application. MN functionalized with 3-aminopropylthriethoxysilane as an C2NH4O2R derivative has been prepared using the chemical co-precipitation method [38-39]. The synthesized material has been used as a substrate for lipase immobilization. Indeed, the amino-MN found a
special application of well dispersed DNA biosensor. It is noted that the naked MN has the capacity to adsorb DNA, but aggregates due to attractive forces reducing the usable surface area for adsorption. Small artificial magnetic particles can be formed synthetically but are non-uniform, not fully crystalline, and not compositionally homogeneous, therefore, it doesn't provide consistent reaction kinetics. Iron oxide coupled to silane compounds may introduce a small positive ionic charge beneficial for restoring dispersion and may facilitate an ionic interaction with DNA. Thus, Furthermore, amino compounds can be covalently bound to MN creating a stable conjugated media. Amino compounds coupled to magnetite derivatized with carboxyl groups are known to have DNA extraction ability [39]. Consequently, DNA can be condensed into ordered structures on the surface of solid supports coated with multivalent cationic silane compounds
2.1.1.4 Ethylene glycol-MN
The ethylene glycol (C2H6O2) complex, also called macrogels in the pharmaceutical industry, is perfectly soluble in water and is not absorbed by humans. The high magnetization of MN polyhedral nanoparticles in C2H6O2 system have been reported, with ferric chloride used as iron sources, C2H6O2 as solvent, in the presence of sodium hydroxide and dodecylamine [40-42]. This results in a well-dispersed and single crystal features of ethylene glycol-Fe3O4 possessing high superparamagnetism almost similar to that of bulk MN. In another study, C2H6O2-Fe3O4, synthesized by direct photopolymerization where the MN acts as semiconductors to produce radicals under UV radiations, eliminates the need for a photoinitiator [43-44]. It should also be pointed out that the major novelty of the aforementioned study was the chance to begin polymerization of C2H6O2 on the surface of MN without the need for any former functionalizations, via benefitting from MN photoinitiator properties under UV irradiation [44]. The surface functionalization of C2H6O2 with vinyl substances prior to being coated with MN under UV irradiation is a step-growth mechanism, resulting in a well-dispersed and homogeneous MN. In another study, ethylene glycol bismercaptoacetate with tetraethyl orthosilate (as a modified ethylene glycol) was attached to MN, showing promising inherent characteristics, such as high surface area and superparamagnetism [45-46]. The functionalization of C2H6O2 towards MN has been utilized to combine the effects of chemotherapy with hypertonia. Its role is to retard clearly via the reticuloendothelial system through the provision of a stealth shielding effect, which delays any further actions [47-48].
2.1.1.5 Organophorous-MN
Organophorous molecules, including phosphonic acid, 3-phosphonopropionic acid, 16- phosphonohexadecanoic acid, alkylphosphonic acid, and their respective salts have been used to modify the surface of MN [49-50]. Organophosphorous compounds appear complementary to organosilicon coupling molecules as they show an excellent affinity towards metals and transitional metal containing supports such as oxides, hydroxides, carbonates, and phosphates. These groups create M-O-P bond via heterocondensation and
coordination. The phosphonic acids and phosphates adsorb at MN’s surface in a mono, bi, or tridentate modes, with the last one resulting in a more stable organic shell [51]. The bifunctional organophosphorous coupling agents would bind onto iron oxide surface selectively through phosphonic acid site, leaving the polar group as a free pendant group, which would open up a wide range of possibilities for specific binding of biomolecules. For that, understanding and knowledge of adsorption mechanism, quantitative adsorption and dispersion stability of MN in aqueous medium have become essential for optimization of synthesis conditions in order to prepare stable MN with uniform and controllable sizes with large number of active functional groups on the surface [50].These series of orientation specific immobilization strategy described can be applied to other proteins, and therefore, it may find potential applications in the design of biosensors, biocatalysts, and bioreactors having immobilized proteins as their biorecognition elements.
2.1.1.6 Carboxyl-MN
The modification of nanomagnetics by carboxyl (COOH) groups is generally done for better stabilization of MN. It was confirmed that COOH-Fe3O4 is better dispersed in organic solvents and oleic acids [52-53]. Physical-adsorption of COOH on the surface of MN was found to occur via the coordination of carboxylate moiety to the Fe atoms at the MN’ surface. The carboxylate moiety acts as ligands for empty coordination sites of surface metal atoms, with two main coordination modes: unidentate and bidentate [54]. MN functionalized with carboxyl groups is very useful for example for isolation of DNA fragments. Compared with conventional methods, work with carboxylated-MN is fast, simple, sensitive, safe and DNA is obtained in high yields and purity. Moreover, application of magnetic carriers does not require special equipment and facilitates automation in routine purifications [52]. This makes the carboyxlated-MN is promising also for the identification of pathogenic bacteria in food industry
2.1.1.7 Chitosan-MN
Among the methods that could be used to produce chitosan-MN are micro emulsion and emulsion polymerization. In situ mineralization has drawn more and more attention, as it is an efficient and environmentally friendly method [55-56]. Usually, conventional methods are complex and carried out under rigorous reaction conditions in high temperature and pressure, inert atmosphere, organic solvents and surfactant, and water/oil system, all of which might limit its practical application in H2O systems [55;58]. However, in situ mineralization synthesis of chitosan-MN is carried out in a water system, and the small, monodispersed, and stable chitosan coated nanoparticles are directly attained from the degradation of the chitosan hydrogel without any specific reaction conditions [59]. Through this reaction, a small amount of chitosan functional groups, including OH and NH2, chelated with the iron ions and delivered the nucleation site for magnetite crystals and endow the materials with special crystal morphology and excellent mechanical properties [59-60].
MN, modified with aromatic compounds, such as cyclodextrin derivatives (βcyclodextrin, silylated –cyclodextrin, carboxylmethyl-β-cyclodextrin), and coupled with Chitosan, have attracted substantial attention (Figure 3). The formation of these complexes contributed to the formation of weak interactions encompassing hydrophobic effect, van de Waals interactions, and H2 bonding. Due to its hydrophobic nature, this complex is suitable for hydrophobic drug delivery systems [61]. Indeed, the modification of Chitosan polymeric chains with –COOH rich compounds, such as N, O-carboxymethyl prior to the incorporation of non-magnetic phase resulted in a number of novel characteristics, such as a good film forming, promising thermostat for localized hyperthermia treatment, better processing properties, electrical, magnetic, hydrophilicity, stability, and adsorption and optical properties [57-60].
Figure 3: A schematic illustration for the formation of chitosan-MN [56].
By taking into account the aforementioned properties, Chitosan-MN could be used for many interesting applications, chiefly amongst them enzyme immobilization. By forming several enzyme support linkages, controlling the bonding strength, and generating a more suitable environment to prevent dissociation, high stabilization of enzymes is possible [62-63]. Some studies applied a reducing agent to modify the structure of immobilized enzyme, which preserved the activity despite repeated use and improve its stability by quenching excess reactive groups.
2.1.1.8 Cellulose-MN
There are efforts to synthesis MN functionalized aminocellulose as a ligand in the Cumediated controlled radical polymerization of styrene. The so-called amino cellulose used to coat the magnetic nanoparticles was 6-deoxy-6(20bis(20aminoethyl)aminoethylamino) cellulose [64-65]. Functionalized MN with cellulose derivatives recently employed to control redox reactions or bioelectrocatalytic transformations at electrode surfaces. The electrical response of MN functionalized with electroactive groups of cellulose derivatives could be controlled by the cyclic attraction or retraction of the modified MM
to and from the electrode surface, respectively. There are several reports on the application of MN functionalized with long alkyl chains of cellulose derivatives as nanocomponents for controlling the hydrophobic properties of electrode surfaces by means of an external magnet. It demonstrated that the cyclic switchable control of the hydrophobic/hydrophilic properties of the electrode surface by the attraction or retraction of the functionalized MN-cellulose to and from the electrodes, by means of the external magnet. In short, MN modified with cellulose could control the hydrophobic/hydrophilic properties of the interface by physically associated or dissociated magnetic particles [65].
3.1.1.9 Peptide-MN nanoparticles
Peptide-functionalized MN possess optimal physical characteristics, including size and stability, is currently used for tumor-homing via fibrin fibronectin complexes and heating capabilities, which can be used for hyperthermia treatment of lung cancer alongside chemotherapy [66-67]. The peptide-MN nanoparticle system is capable of treating a multitude of cancerous tumors, since it recognizes fibrinogen complexes rather than specific surface integration, which are often cell-line dependent [68].
2.1.1.10 Polymethymetacrylate-MN
Poly(methyl methacrylate) (PAMAN) is a common synthetic organic polymer traditionally used in various industrial applications. Recent research has revealed that PMMA can be used as a powerful absorbent for the enrichment of peptides and proteins. Therefore, the design and synthesis of magnetic nanomaterials with PAMAN at the surface are of particular interest in projects, requiring fast and convenient enrichment of peptides or proteins [69]. In indeed, the functionalization of MN with PAMAM not only reduce MN agglomeration due to the dipole-dipole interaction of MN, but could also be used as a good template and proper stabilizing agent during the synthesis of MN and improve its chemical stability [69-71]. Functionalization with PAMAM change the interparticle interactions of MN, such as the collective state and non-equilibrium dynamics, are presented. Besides, PAMAM also tunned the surface anisotropy and disorder, spin-wave excitations, as well as the enhancements of the coercive field and particle magnetization of MN. This consequently resulted in the functionality to PAMAM dendrimers with a high density of terminal groups, leading to a high number of active sites of MN particles [70;72].
2.1.11 Polyglycerol-MN
The functionalization of MN with hyper branched polyglycerol (PG) via an esterification technique helps water solubility. It was pointed out that MN tends to aggregate in aqueous mediums despite its hydrophilic nature, due to its high specific surface area and high levels of surface free energy [73-74]. Consequently, the hydrophilic polymeric compounds PG act as stabilizers to change the surface properties of MN. On the other hand, the tendency of MN to apply itself directly with active compounds is low, therefore, surface functionalization with PG becomes more significant [75]. PG-MN have
been synthesized using different methods, including inorganic sol gel reaction and thiolene click chemistry [76-77].
2.1.2 Inorganic compound functionalized MN

sections.heading: 2.1.2.1 GO-MN
sections.text:
Inorganic-MN, are nontoxic and acceptable for biotechnology and biomedical applications, due to facile synthesis, smaller size of the core, chemical stability, nontoxic, non-carcinogenic nature, and large surface areas.
GO-functionalized MN is capable of preventing the aggregation and improve the general catalytic activity due to its strong synergistic interaction between both components [80]. Its abundant oxygenated functional groups, such as the hydroxyl and epoxides on the basal plane with the carbonyl and carboxyl groups at the edges act as nucleation sites for metal ions in functionalizing GO-MN. The formation of Go-MN through conjugation chemistry is typically done through in-situ reduction of iron salt precursors [78;81]. However, there are some difficulties associated with recent reported methodologies, including poor control over the size, size distribution, and the location of the MN. In addition, thus-prepared GO-MN may agglomerate and slowly precipitate from their respective aqueous suspension [79-80].
The surface of GO-MN have been functionalized for the monodispersed single particle. For example, the loading of some O2 containing functional compounds, such as epoxy, carboxylic, and hydroxyl doxorubin hydrochloride onto GO-MN results in a more hydrophilic surface, while the presence of the carboxylic group resulted in a good physiological stability, low cyctotoxicty, and multi-targeting nanoparticles (Table 2).
Table 2: Functionalized GO-MN with the respective applications
No Functionalized GO-Fe3O4 Applications References 1 2,3 dimercaptosuccinic acid- GO-Fe3O4 Biosensor 82 2 Polyethylenimine-GO-(2,3-dimercaptosuccinic Fe3O4) Adsorbent 83 3 Meso-2,3-dimercaptosuccinic acid and aminodextran-
Fe3O4-GO
Adsorbent 84
Recent studies have reported the applications of GO-MN as a catalyst for the reduction of nitrobenzene, oxidation of cysteine, methyl orange, and 3,3,5,5-tetramethylbenzidine [82;85-86]. Furthermore, GO-MN is also of interest in biology and biomedical applications, such as targeted drug delivery (doxorubicin hydrochloride), immunoassays, hyperthermia, magnetic resonance imaging contrast improvement, energy storage, removal of contaminants from wastewater and separation, and DNA detection [87].
2.1.2.2 ZrO2-MN
Functionalized zirconia (ZrO2) to MN surfaces overcame some aggregation and rapid biodegradation problems associated with MN. Due to its excellent properties and a welldefined core structure, ZrO2-MN have been utilized extensively as electrodes (Figure 4). For example, enzyme immobilization on the surface of ZrO2-MN resulted in high trapping capacity and good electro catalytic and easy isolated electrode for the H2O2 reduction [89-90]. Meanwhile, the modification of MN by ZrO2 has also been explored as an adsorbent for the speciation of chromium species in several kinds of environmental water and biological samples.
Figure 4: TEM images of (a) Fe3O4; (b) Fe3O4@C; (c) Fe3O4@ZrO2; and (d) CZMMs [89].
2.1.3 Organic doped MN

sections.heading: 2.1.3.1 C: MN
sections.text:
The produced organic-doped MN can simultaneously exhibit two or more functionalities, namely tenable multicolor luminescence, magnetic response, plasmonic properties, biological activity, drug delivery capability, catalytic activity, and others.
In recent years, carbon-doped MN (C:MN) have been produced and employed as suitable sorbents in magnetic solid phase extraction of different environmental waste, including 2,4,6-tribromophenol, tetrabromobisphenol A, 4,4’-dibromodiphenyl ether and 4,4’- dibromobiphenol with different hydrophobicity, hydrogen bonding ability, and polarity [91-92]. It has been reported that there are organic groups decorating the surface of C:MN, with hydrophobic interactions coupled with hydrogen bonding or dipole-dipole interaction between C:MN and the waste molecules. Recently, a green approach on room-temperature synthesized of C;MN prepared by a co-sputtering technique. Perpendicular magnetic anisotropy was obtained for the doped MN with C concentrations up to 25 vol % and coercivity enhancement was observed with small C doped MN A clear spin-reorientation transition from perpendicular to the in-plane direction was observed
with an increase in carbon concentration. The observed magnetic properties are intercorrelated to microstructural changes that occur as a function of the C doping.
2.1.4 Inroganic doped MN

sections.heading: 2.1.4.1 F:MN
sections.text:
It has been demonstrated that fluorine, as amphiphilic copolymers, produces MN with stable and well organized properties, due to its great hydrophobicity, excellent thermal stability, and low surface energy [93]. The strong hydrophobic interactions and high fluidity of the fluorine-based compounds are supposed to interact strongly with the hydrophobic nanoparticles and keep the magnetomicelles stable in the circulation. The fluorine compounds construct a stable hydrophobic core, thus reducing the cyctotoxicity of the hybrid system [94].
2.1.4.2 Ln:MN
Lanthanide doped MN (Ln: MN), composed of MN coated with amine modified silica hell, is modified with Ln3+ ions coordinated polyacrylic acid molecules. Ln:MN is intensively investigated due their application to various scientific and industrial endevours. MN doped with Ln3+ emitted different colours, depending on the dopant ion with long luminescence lifetimes, narrow emission bands, and a photo-stability (Figure 5). Ln:MN is also resistant to photo-bleaching, high temperature, redox processes, aggressive agents, and UV radiation. Such luminescent MN can potentially be used in multimodal imaging, hyperthermia treatment, targeted photodynamic therapy, selective drug delivery, water purification, and enrichment of trace elements or substances. The products obtained from stable aqueous colloidal exhibited bright red or green luminescence and responded to applied magnetic fields.
MN hybrids have been subjected to extensive research due to their potential applications in catalyst, adsorption, sensors, solar cells, lithium ion batteries, and bio related fields, Due to its suitable particle size, biocompatibility, high magnetization, and superparamagnetism.
2.2.1 Polymer hybrid MN
The incorporation of a polymer matrix, acting as a support, coating, or substrate is an appropriate strategy that prevents agglomeration. Polymer coating leads to the formation of more hydrophilic MN, and create a variety of surface functional groups that are available to prevent aggregation and enhance the stability of MN.
3.2.1.1 Polyethylene glycol/MN nanohybrid
Polyethyelene glycol (PEG) is a linear polyether whose attachment onto MN surface provides a stealth shielding effect, delaying the action normally provided by MN [97-98]. The prime challenge in synthesizing PEG/MN hybrid is to coat the nanoparticles down to nanometric dimensions [99]. Therefore, several researchers have come out with novel synthesis method by direct photo-polymerization of magnetite nanoparticles [100-101]. Through this method, the semiconductor properties of MN are tuned to generate radical under UV radiations, without any need for a photo-initiator.
Functionalized PEG, such as folic acid-polyethylene glycol (Figure 6) and ethylene glycol bis-mercaptoacetate modified tetraethyl orthosilicate was functionalized with MN and used to apply for extraction and preconcentration on the detection of the organic compounds [102-103].
Figure 6: Steps in the synthesis of folic acid-modified, PEG/MN conjugated with doxorubicin [99].
2.2.1.2 Polyimide/MN nanohybrid
The incorporation of MN into polyimide (PI) matrix provides extraordinary physical and chemical properties, including high specific surface area, low toxicity, superparamagnetism and simple separation by an external magnet [104-105]. This paves the way for PI/MN hybrid to be used various applications such as low dielectric material, high temperature nano containers, and confined reaction vessels with heat resistance [104;106]. The preparation of PI/MN films has attracted considerable attention, including deposition, solgel, and in-situ method. In-situ synthesis is a typical method of fabricating PI/MN. Fe(CO)5 contained in poly(amic acid) (PAA) film decomposes to its corresponding oxide throughout curing of the film [107]. The MN must be kept at a low content to preserve the mechanical property of the PI. Controlled dispersion of MN in PI matrix is another important factor in the design fabrication and processing plans, where the aggregation of the nanoparticles is prevented. To deal with this, amine-functionalized MN, derived from pyrometallic dianhydride/4,4’-oxydianiline, has been used as a
polyimide precursor (Figure 7). This methodology contributes to the interaction between nanoparticles and PI matrix, where the polyimide macromolecules separate MN [107- 109].
Figure 7: The reaction procedure for the amine-MN and PI matrix. [107]
2.2.1.3 Polydopamine/MN nanohybrid
Polydopamine (PA) has significantly attracted the attention of researchers due to its potential of hybridizing MN and its prospective properties, including coating quality and functionality. PA monomer covers both catechol and amine functional groups and selfpolymerizes at alkaline pH values [110]. For the period of polymerization, PA instinctively, creates a conformal and continuous coating layer atop nearly any material present in the reaction media, such as MN (Figure 8). The PA/MN hybrid layer thickness will possibly be controlled by adjusting the dopamine concentration and reaction time [111-113]. The produced hybrid layered system have been employed to be utilized in abundance for developed applications such as the separation and enrichment of proteins in proteomic analysis, the detection of pollutants by matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time of flight mass spectrometry, and magnetic solid-phase extraction adsorbent for the determination of trace polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons in environmental samples [112;114]. To control the synthesis of core shell of PA/MN with tunable shell thickness, some works focused on the creation of a nanostructured metal catalyst support. Using Polydopamine as reducing agent, PA/MN could be used as a platform to grow MN. These nanostructures were easily separated and recycled, and demonstrated high catalytic performance. PA is also known to lessen metal salts within a solution into MN by the catechol functional groups [111;115]. Monolayers, as a second surface, was modified for biosensor and support of bio-mineralization and freestanding films. To increase the wettable properties of PA/MN, fluorination functionalization has been introduced to its surface. The bifunctional of PA/MN-fluorination microspheres is favorable, with super hydrophobicity, high stability, easy repair ability, high absorption capacity, superb re-cyclability for oil/water separation and superparamagnetism
properties. In another study, a glutathione functionalized PA/MN was introduced for the analyses of proteomic. The PA coating was deposited from an aqueous solution onto MN, where they were then allowed to react with glutathione. With the deposition of Pt nanoparticles, the electrocatalytic properties of PA/MN are increased simultaneously. Indeed, silica coated PA/MN resulted in significant positive impact on the adsorption capacity for protein, fibrinogen, hemoglobin, and myoglobin [116-118].
Figure 8: TEM image of PA/MN (a), VSM magnetization curves (b) and FTIR spectra (c) of MN and PA/MN [112].
Generally, PA/MN has been widely used for environmental protection. The use of PA as an affinity material for organic pollutants results in numerous benefits, such as biocompatibility, dispensability in water, multi-functional groups, and the provision of the ᴨᴨ stacking interaction with the target [117;119]. The PA wall is used as reactive templates, with carbonyl-MN as its core material in order to construct hierarchical structure, which is consequently used as a water repellent after fluorination.
2.2.1.4 Polylactic acid/MN
To comply with the criteria of hydrophilicity and bio-compatibility, an efficient surface modification incorporation of polylactic acid (PLA) with MN will result in better selectivity and low release rate for drug delivery applications [120-121]. The magnetic targeted drug delivery system, with high saturation magnetization value, was prepared based on PLA/MN core/shell nanohybrid for controlled release methotrexate [122].
2.2.1.5 Poly(cyclotriphosphazene-co-4,4-sulfonyldiphenol)/MN
Highly cross linked and bio-compatible poly(cyclotriphosphazene-co-4,4sulfonyldiphenol) was utilized to directly coat MN micro-spheres by a facile but effective
one pot polycondensation (Figure 9) [123]. The achieved core-shell Poly(cyclotriphosphazene-co-4,4-sulfonyldiphenol)/MN had negligible cytotoxicity and magnetic manipulation and magnetic resonance imaging properties [124-125].
Figure 9: Micrograph images of (a) poly(cyclotriphosphazene-co-4,4-sulfonyldiphenol nanofibers, and (b) magnetic poly(cyclotriphosphazene-co-4,4-sulfonyldiphenol Fe3O4/PZS nanofibers [123].
2.2.2 Metal/metal oxide MN
2.2.2.1 Pt/MN
It was demonstrated that the incorporation of Pt in Pt/MN structure results in a 20-fold growth in mass activity towards O2 reduction reaction compared with single-component Pt. The synergistic effect between Pt and MN active sites could potentially boost electrocatalytic activity and prevent oxidation and aggregation of MN (Figure 10). The result of this interaction produced dumbbell-like nanoparticles, with interesting catalytic, optical, and magnetic properties, which consequently offer an ideal nanosystem for catalytic and biomedical applications [127-129]. This consequently influenced the activity and durability of the catalytic system. The promising applications include catalyst for H2O2 reduction, immunosensor to detect antibody, glassy electrode, and clinical analysis [127;130]. In order to improve the surface chemistry, thermodynamics, magnetism electrochemistry, and stability, the surface of Pt/MN could be further functionalized. This attracted a lot of interest from the catalysis, transistor, drug delivery, enzyme immobilization, molecular recognition, and sensor communities.
Figure 10: Dumbbell-like Pt/MN Nanoparticles and Their Enhanced Catalysis for Oxygen Reduction Reaction [127].
3.2.2.2 Au/MN
The hybridization of gold (Au) is one strategy of stabilizing MN. Indeed, the incorporation of Au into MN matrix is due to its noble property of electron transfer, strong coupling interaction towards MN, and high sensitivity properties [131-132]. The surface chemistry of Au demonstrates excellent properties that are suitable for functionalization, is able to offer great stability to MN in solution, and assist in binding several chemical and biological agents [133]. Many articles have described effective chemical techniques in synthesizing stable mono-dispersed Au/MN with the required size. These methods include co-precipitation, thermal decomposition, reversed micelle technique, and the solvo-thermal method. All aforementioned methods supposedly produced two types of Au/MN; bi-layer and multilayer structure. Bi-layer structures, which are the standard, consists of two layers: the core and Au shell [131-134]. Multilayer composite structures consist of more than two layers (Figure 11). There are three layers; the core, the glue material (SiO2, polymers and others) the Au shell.
Figure 11: Hybrid Au/MNNanoflowers [135].
One of the promising applications of Au-MN is the detection of biomolecules in biosensors due to excellent bio-compatibility, magnetic properties, low toxicity, and high stability. The Au/MN show high magnetic response to an externally applied magnetic field, and can be used for selective capture of bio-target, recycle nanocatalysis, and magnetic photonic purpose. Moreover, coating the magnetic particles with Au shell can facilitate a strong plasmonic resonant optical response, and also a well-organized surface chemistry [135-136]. Therefore, Au-MN in biosensor results in many advantages, including the rapid production of the biosensor, with the modified nanoparticles under chemically mild conditions under an external magnetic field, high surface-to-volume ratio, and biocompatibility of Au, influencing better sensitivity, less clustered aggregation when Au-MN is directly used, and simply renewable surface of the electrode exposed to an external magnetic field. On the other hands, Au/MN is an ideal candidate for many other applications, including protein separation, cellular biosensor, multimodal imaging, photothermal destruction of cancer cells, electrochemiluminescence immunosensor, photothermal cancer cell killing, photothermo chemotherapy, multimodal cancer imaging, and surface enhanced Raman scattering, as well as surface plasmon resonance [137-138].
However, the restriction of the Au electrode, together with the instability under physiological conditions, the formation of harmful free radical and inappropriate surface binding of the ligand resulted from MN limiting its application of the electrochemical sensor [132-133]. Therefore, the surface modification of Au/MN will result in great advantages, such as high chemo selectivity, high yield without any release of by product, no need to control temperature/pressure settings, ease of access of two active groups, and irretrievable nature that affects in a stable linkage. There are many different approaches to the modification or functionalization of the Au/MN surfaces with different materials, such as polymers (amine, carboxylate), organic monolayers (homocysteine, 11- mercaptoundecanoic acid, 11-dodecanethiol), oxides and metals [136;139] (Figure 12). For example, in order to improve solubility in water, the surface of Au/MN was functionalized with hydrophilic thiol.
Figure 12: A Flower-like Au−MN Optical Nanosensor [136].
3.2.2.3 Ag/MN
The silver (Ag), Ag/MN not only retain the advantages of both Ag and MN, but it also reflects the excellent synergistic sensitizing effect, which consequently improve the transfer efficiency of the electrode surface [140-141] (Figure 13). Ag/MN, with its Ag exposed, is a kind of multifunctional nanomaterial that combines the advantages of magnetic material and nano silver, realizing the effective magnetic separation of nanosized antimicrobials against Gran-negative Escherichi coli and Gram-positive Bacillus subtilis. Its antibacterial abilities, mainly rely on stabilities and Ag+ release properties. However, excessive exposure of Ag, and therefore the high release speed restricts the practical application of Ag/MN with its Ag exposed [142-143].
Figure 13: A novel magnetically recyclable Ag-based catalyst has been synthesized in one pot, and it is found that this catalyst is highly efficient in selectively catalyzing styrene conversion to styrene oxide [140].
There are a lot of synthetic methods for preparing Ag/MN, such as solvo-thermal, hydrothermal, thermal decomposition, and a two-step chemical method. Generally, a thermal decomposition reaction between solid mixtures of silver acetate and ferric oxide micro-spheres with reducing agents or linkers are used to decorate ferric oxide with Ag nanoparticles [144]. There are many reports on the intrinsic disadvantages of these methods, such as complex production routes, as well as the utilization of reducing agents, such as hydrazine, sodium borohydride, dimethyl formide, and aniline. These agents are highly reactive chemicals, and cause possible environmental and biological hazards. There are some reports focused on the usage of environmentally benign and renewable materials to produce Ag/MN [145-146]. The first green method for synthesizing of Ag/MN is using the aqueous stem extract of Vitis vinifera, with no hazardous chemicals used as solvents or reducing and stabilizing agents during the synthesis. Another simple fabrication of a type of magnetite-carbon core shell microsphere is done by coating Ag
nanoparticles on the surface through in-situ reduction of AhNO3 with butylamine to produce three-ply composite microsphere. There are also reports of approaches that produce highly effective and reproducible Ag/MN. The as-synthesized Ag/MN possessed well-defined structures and uniform properties (Figure 14). For example, the synthesis of Ag/MN uses one pot fabrication in a water phase solution of AgNO3 and FeCl3 as precursors and ethylene glycol as reductant, showing good interactions between magnetic and Ag nanoparticles. Moreover, an SiO2 layer has been introduced between the Ag/MN interface to form unique hollow structures and physical mechanics features. The produced hybrid is uniform in shape, float on the surface of water, and adsorb more solar light, and could thus be used for environmental treatment [147].
Figure 14: Core/shell structured MN/Au and MN/Au/Ag nanoparticles are synthesized by depositing Au and Ag on the MN surface in aqueous solution at room temperature [146].
3.2.3 Ceramic hybrid MN
3.2.3.1 SiO2/MN
The development of silica oxide (SiO2), SiO2/MN as potential elements for supporting catalyst has been reviewed recently. This provides for the magnetic nanoparticles to be simply separated and recycled from the products via an external magnet, preventing the loss of the solid catalyst in a straightforward process [148-149]. SiO2’s surface can be easily functionalized with various organic groups for any desired purpose, including applications as adsorbent, catalysis support, enzyme immobilization, and others (Figure 15). The attractive features of SiO2/MN are promising alternative to porous/mesoporous catalysis for the oxidation of olefins and alcohols [149-150].
Figure 15:Amide-Surface functionalization of SiO2/MN [149].
3.2.3.2 TiO2/MN nanohybrid
The improvement of catalytic activities of titanium oxide (TiO2), TiO2/MN core shell can be taken to mean the energy level theory; the energy level of Fe 3+ /Fe 2+ is closest to the energy level of TiO2’s conduction band, while the energy level of Fe 3+ /Fe 4+ is closest to the energy level of TiO2 valence bands, whereby Fe 3+ dissolved from MN can come into not only electron capture positions, but also hole capture position [151-153]. This consequently causes the electron-hole pair recombination of TiO2 to decrease.
There are various synthesis routes that could be used to prepare TiO2/MN, including the solgel process, co-precipitation, hydrothermal treatment, spray pyrolysis, sonochemical synthesis, and wet impregnation methods [153-155]. The solgel method has been applied to fabricate the coating of nanosized crystalline TiO2 directly onto magnetic core particles. Indeed, some works also synthesized the cryptomelane-type manganese oxide nanowires, and then loaded with TiO2 nanoparticles via the hydrothermal method, which finally coated the MN with a co-precipitation method. However, direct contact between magnetic materials and TiO2 photocatalysts usually results in an unfavorable heterojunction, leading to an increase in electron-hole recombination and photodissolution phenomenon [154]. Therefore, there are some attempt at introducing insulating materials, such as SiO2 between MN and TiO2 shells, which prevents electrons from being conveyed to the magnetic iron oxide and avoid iron leaching.
3.2.4 Carbon based/MN
The combination of carbon and MN provides a thin layer of hydrophilic carbon material covering the surface of magnetic nanoparticles to generate carbon-coated MN, which should solve the desorption problem. Activated carbon (AC) has been widely used as a coating material in AC/MN. MN could easily form large aggregates that could in theory manipulate their magnetic properties. The incorporation of AC also contributes to the high adsorption properties of AC/MN. Superparamagnetic AC/MN sorbent has been prepared through hydrothermal reaction of glucose with an iron source, and applied as magnetic sorbent and solid phase extraction for polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon [156- 157]. Compared to conventional AC sorbent, the AC/MN demonstrated appropriate functional modification, high separation efficiency, high reusability, and environmental friendliness. A distinct advantage of this technology is the magnetic materials supported with carbon dispersed into sample solution to adsorb target analytes, and subsequently, the materials could be collected quickly and efficiently using magnet, and then, the adsorbed analyses could be elucidated with organic solvents (Figure 16) [158].
Figure 16: The formation process of AC/MN and its application as adsorbent [157].
There are several methods to synthesize AC/MN. Coated MN micro-sphere with hydrophilic AC has been prepared via hydrothermal reaction for the core-shell-structured AC/MN, which endows MN micro-spheres with better dispensability and stability compared to as-synthesized MN, on top of considerably improving the affinity between hybrid components [157-159]. Another study synthesized AC coated magnetic nanorods as anode materials for Li batteries. AC encapsulated magnetic nanoparticles could also be produced by a carbon arc plasma route and applied as separable and mobile sorbents of heavy metal ions. AC/MN with an average size of 100 to 200 nm, results in better surface properties and can be further modified by biomolecules [160].
Previously, organic groups were used to decorate the hydrophobic and hydrophilic characters of AC/MN. It was found that there were hydrophobic interactions, coupled with hydrogen bonding or dipole-dipole interaction between AC/MN and targeted adsorbents, such as 2,4,6-tribromophenol, tetrabromobisphenol A, 4,4’-dibromodiphenyl ether, 4,4’-dibromobiphenyl from environmental wastes [161-162]. Furthermore, the surface of AC/MN, decorated with ionic surfactant such as alkyl carboxylates chemisorbing, produces magnetic adsorbent at low costs, high adsorption efficiency, and a less time consuming operation of samples passing through the column.
The architectures of MN decorated carbon nanotubes (CNTs) exhibit excellent adsorption, durability, large surface area, interesting magnetic properties, appropriate functional modification, high separation efficiency, high reusability, environmental friendliness, and thermal excellence [163-164]. It was found that CNTs/MN shows excellent microwave adsorption property in the GHz range. The promising adsorption ability also renders the CNTs/MN well-dispersed into solutions to adsorb target analytes, and subsequently, the materials could be collected quickly and appropriately with a magnet, and then, the adsorbed analytes are elated with organic solvents. The CNTs/MN forms an electrode surface that acts as sensors for dopamine molecules.
The synthesis of CNTs/MN began with the growth of CNTs and decoration of MN on the surface of CNTs via a pressure-assisted precursor pyrolysis technique and gel soaking curing reaction. Both elements could generate general self-assembly via hydrogen bonding, electrostatic attraction, ᴨ-ᴨ stacking, donor-acceptor, van der Waals, and hydrophilic and hydrophobic interactions (Figure 17) [165].
Figure 17: Thiol-functionalized CNTs/MN [165].
The preparation of graphene/MN is done by intercalating MN onto the lamellar structure of reduced oxide graphene, which prevented the aggregation and oxidation of MN [166]. Moreover, due to the special magnetism and excellent electrical conductivity, reduced oxide graphene based composite materials with MN are highly desirable for rapidly assembling functionalized sensing interfaces, such as imprinted polymer, sandwichcasting, as well as accelerating electron transfer and improving the catalytic activity in the electrochemical and biological sensor. This consequently improved the ultra-sensitive assays of graphene/MN. Doping reduced graphene/MN to form the three dimensional structures of hybrid materials could be another attempt that possesses the advantages of rapid assembly and easy immobilization, besides promoting electrical conductivity [167]. The thickness and morphological properties of the hybrid system could be easily controlled by adjusting the concentrations of MN or reduced graphene.
4.0 Application of modified MN
4.1 Heterogeneous Catalyst
The demand for an environmentally benign procedure with heterogeneous and reusable catalyst motivated researchers to search for a safe alternate technique to synthesize organic and inorganic reactions. The purpose of these investigations is to figure out the
synergistic impacts of combined use of recyclable strong solid acid catalyst with inherent magnetic properties for the enhancement of new eco-compatible strategy [20;24]. It was reported that the application of functionalized magnetic nanoparticles results in better reaction process, including reaction time, catalyst loading, reaction temperature, and reactant concentration, with reduced waste production and uninterrupted production. Most notably, the magnetic supported catalysts indicate high catalytic activity and a high degree of chemical stability, and they do not swell in organic solvents [48;55]. According to these attractive properties, many functionalized MN has been designed and widely applied, either as a catalyst or catalyst support in traditional metal catalysis, organocatalysis, and even enzyme catalysis [151-152] (Table 3).

4.2 Food security
Nanostructures has been remarkably applied in recent work involving food security. One of the most well known techniques concentrated on the utilization of MN possessing several benefits arising from the natural characteristics of these materials, including high surface area and superparamagnetism, which can be easily performed by applying an
external magnetic field and suspended MN with analytes from a large volume sample using a strong magnet [58;61]. Such bio-detectable food security employ functionalized molecules that identify specific cell receptors on the semiconductor carriers to improve their respective targeting efficacy.
4.2 Biomedical
For biomedical applications, it is necessary to obtain a stable colloidal suspension of magnetic nanoparticles. However, due to the Van der Waals forces and magnetic dipolar interactions, magnetic nanoparticles tend to agglomerate. Therefore, the functionalized MN found promising application in the biomedical field, especially for cell separation, magnetic resonance imaging, protein separation, and cancer treatments [71]. These functionalized nanomaterials are appropriate for in-vivo applications, as well as cellular applications, assisting the internalization of magnetic nanoparticles, especially for human cells, managing its efficacy for hyperthermia therapies. Additionally, the size, shape, and dispersibility in biological medium and chemical stability of surface functionalized magnetic nanoparticles are considered as fundamental factors specifying the potential of the aforementioned materials in biomedical applications [113].
4.3 Drug delivery
For efficient drug delivery, the loading efficiency, stability, biodegradability, non-toxicity in the physicological medium, high magnetic saturation, site directed drug targeting, reduce amount of drug side effects are some of the main factors that needs to be taken into account [82;90]. The strategy on drug delivery approaches using functionalized MN can be pointed out many routes, including hydrogel based vector, drug modification by chemical means, drug encapsulation in vesicles, controlled release system, and inorganic hollow nanoshells. On the vessel wall, the drug can either be released directly into the blood stream, or a biological technique can be employed to confirm the uptake of the particles into tissue, causing a tissue-specific release of drugs and the minimization of side effects [99-100]. Therefore, the surface of MN could be engineered with several simultaneous biomedical related functions. Interest in using functionalize MN to realize an efficient drug delivery system arising from its mechanical, chemical, electrical, optical, magnetic, electro-optical, and magneto-optical properties. The functionalized MN used in a smart delivery system with a strong ability to solve several existing problems, such as the development of cell based system, the targeting of drugs to specific cells, the creation of novel vaccine delivery approaches, and antibodies attaching to the surface.
The functionalized compounds of MN, including silica, chitosan, and poly ɛ caprolactone are some of the current compound used to functionalized MN. Poly(ethyl-2cyanoacrylate) and bovine serum albumin is always essential for the enhancement of drug delivery systems. It should also be be taken into consideration that the saturation magnetization value of the frug loaded polymer-magnetic composition reported in
literature is much lower than the corresponding bare MN due to the creation of a nonmagnetic shell, brought to the insensitive magnetic fields.
4.4 Hydrothermia treatment
Hyperthermia treatments including whole body and regional hyperthermia, have several disadvantages, such as damaging healthy tissues, limited penetration of heat into the body, under dosage of heat and complications such as increased heat rate and increased cardiac output. In that context, magnetic fluid hyperthermia is regarded as a form of cancer therapy, where the MN are internalized in a cancer tumor, and upon the application of an oscillating magnetic field, a localized temperature increase is obtained inducing tumor remission. In this treatment, an oscillating magnetic field induces rotational motion of the MN, which dissipates energy [74]. The functionalization of MN is expected to increase the energy dissipation for magnetic fluid hyperthermia by increasing its anti-cancer effects. It was reported that functionalized MN has the ability to target tumors passively or actively, and in the presence of an external magnetic field, can generate heat via multiple possible loss mechanisms, including Neel paramagnetic switching, friction losses from Brownian rotation, and hysteresis [94]. Meanwhile, the functionalization of MN via the coating method with biocompatible polymer is used to prevent aggregation and biodegradation for in-vivo applications. With respect to their size, surface functionalization, and hydrophilicity, a rapid uptake of uncoated nanoparticles by the mononuclear phagocyte system is likely to occur after systematic administration, followed by clearance to the liver, spleen, and bone marrow [120].
4.6 Wastewater treatment
The novelty of magnetic separable systems has attracted a significant amount of attention in recent years as an interesting alternative for improving the efficient separation steps upon wastewater reaction completion by employing a simple magnet, providing enhanced reusability of the designed systems, as well as upgrading its corresponding properties, depending on the selected approach [37-39].
For example, the MN polymer hybrid particle has widely been used to remove traces of heavy metal ions in solution. The same approach was shown for MN functionalized with SiO2, where Bismuthiol II could be immobilized. The resulting functionalized nanoparticles could be applied as solid phase extraction adsorbent to remove traces of Cr, Cu and Pb from environmental aqueous samples [110].
5.0 Conclusion
In recent years MN has been the center of attention due to properties such as stability in physiological conditions, bio-compatibility, superparamagnetic property, and high moment in low magnetic fields. These unique electrical and magnetic properties are based on the transfer of electrons between Fe 2+ and Fe 3+ ions at the octahedral sites. For the magnetic nanoparticles to be effective, it must be relatively mono-dispersed, highly crystalline, water dispersible, and bio-compatible. Therefore, surface modification of MN
is a strategy of stabilizing MN by coating with inorganic layers (silica, carbon), or combined-coating with organic substances (surfactant and polymers). Due to the modification through adsorption or bonding with the MN surface, the surface force of OH groups was reduced, and the H2 bonds between the particles are removed, not allowing for the formation of O2 bridge bonds as the MN are frying, thus preventing agglomeration. On a different note, the modified MN has gained increasing interest due to its potential applications in catalysis, food security, biomedical, enzyme immobilization, drug delivery, and organic compounds removal from wastewater.

metadata.abstractText: Iron oxide magnetic nanoparticles have aroused the interest of researchers of materials’ chemistry due to its exceptional properties such as decent magnetic, electric, catalytic, biocompatibility, and low toxicity. However, these magnetic nanoparticles are predisposed towards aggregation and forming larger particles, due to its strong anisotropic dipolar interactions, particularly in the aqueous phase, consequently depriving them of dispersibility and particular properties, ultimately degrading their performance. Hence, this review focuses on modified magnetic nanoparticles that are stable, easily synthesized, possess a high surface area and could be facile-separated via magnetic forces, and are of low toxicity and costs for applications such as catalyst/catalyst support, food security, biomedical, and pollutant remediation.
